awd_titl_txt: The effect of material properties and scaling on wetting of membranes used in membrane distillation
awd_abstract_narration:
Development of energy-efficient treatment methods to treat nonconventional water sources will help to address global water scarcity. Membrane distillation can treat high-salinity and/or highly contaminated waters, for which conventional treatment processes are impractical. Membrane distillation uses low-grade energy, supplied from waste heat and/or solar thermal energy, to vaporize (rather than boil) non-potable water streams. The membrane allows water vapor to pass, while restricting permeation of liquid water and its dissolved solutes.  Design of membrane distillation processes involves a number of simplifying assumptions, in particular, that the membrane is impermeable to liquid water and its dissolved solutes. However, with time, dissolved solutes form a scaling layer on the membrane, compromising the ability of the membrane to exclude liquid water and solutes. This project will develop a new model to address the performance of membrane distillation processes that is consistent with long-term operation of practical, heterogeneous membranes.

This project will develop a new model for liquid entry pressure that incorporates operating conditions, membrane chemistry, asymmetric membrane properties, and the effect of a scaling layer. The model will incorporate experiments that probe internal and distillate-side membrane properties on pore wetting, simple and complex feed solution chemistries, and consider both single- and multi-component scaling conditions. Both commercial membranes and novel polymer membranes that vary hydrophobicity versus hydrophilicity will be considered. An extended Washburn method will quantify the internal hydrophobicity of the porous membranes. A techno-economic assessment will quantify the key impacts of high-performance membranes for high-salinity applications. The project will support graduate and postdoctoral training, while also expanding educational outreach to underrepresented and low-income high school students on energy-efficient water production. The project will enable better performance, prediction, and identification of membrane design improvements for challenging, high-salinity applications that approach zero liquid discharge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Membrane distillation (MD) is a competitive process for treating challenging, high-salinity streams. While emerging pressure-driven processes such as high-pressure reverse osmosis, osmotically assisted reverse osmosis, and low-salt-rejection reverse osmosis, are also being considered for high-salinity and/or high-recovery applications, these processes are complicated by membrane compaction, membrane fouling, and heat management of high-pressure pumps. MD can achieve high rejection and recovery at low pressures and with lower fouling rates as long as membrane wetting-resistance is maintained. Especially when treating high-salinity brines, maintaining wetting resistance is a key challenge. This multi-year project was focused on developing a comprehensive mechanistic understanding of wetting resistance and liquid progression in distillation membranes.

 

In the first study, we introduced the concept of liquid-entry-pressure distribution to characterize membrane wetting resistance by incorporating pore size heterogeneity. We demonstrated that the distribution of liquid entry pressures as well as the skewness, or asymmetry, of the distribution, can be used to not only predict the occurrence of wetting, but also to semi-quantitatively predict liquid flux during MD. When liquid-entry-pressure distributions were characterized by negative skewness, significant or measurable salt passage did not occur. We also found that reducing pore size is equally as, or more effective than, increasing contact angle to resist pore wetting, especially for scaling-induced wetting. The results of this study challenged past emphasis on increasing hydrophobicity alone to improve the wetting resistance of MD membranes.

 

We then studied wetting of a variety of membranes exposed to different feed solution chemistries in MD. By differentiating liquid flux from vapor flux for the first time, we observed that two distinct modes of wetting exist: “constant wetting” mode, which is characterized by a linear increase in the distillate salinity and constant liquid flux, and “increasing wetting” mode, which is characterized by an exponential increase in distillate salinity and increasing liquid flux. We also introduced “solute mixing” as an experimental artifact that presents as decreasing liquid flux and can obscure identification of wetting onset. We observed that pore size had a greater effect on liquid flux than on vapor flux. Similar to pore size, we observed that membrane thickness had a greater effect on liquid flux than on vapor flux. Thus, we also demonstrated trade-offs between vapor and liquid flux due to differences in pore size and membrane thickness.

 

We developed a novel method to characterize compaction of membranes in real-time under low pressure by combining the ability of dynamic mechanical analysis to apply a precisely controlled force with the ability of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy to detect membrane deformation. Using short- and long-term mechanical tests we found that initial instant compaction contributed more to total compaction than subsequent instant compaction. We also found that the contribution of creep to total compaction increases significantly with applied pressure. Finally, we introduced creep/instant compaction ratio as a key indicator of material resilience. We are currently extending the applicability of this method to higher pressures.

 

Next, we used electrochemical impedance spectroscopy to characterize the wetting front and liquid progression through MD membranes in real-time. The precise moment of impedance drop identified the onset of wetting, the slope of the impedance-time curve determined the speed of wetting, and the magnitude of impedance reduction estimated the depth of the wetting front in the membrane. We found that PTFE membranes typically operate in an internally wetted state without pore breakthrough. The pause/termination of wetting progression may be due to fibril hydrophobicity at the pore walls that maintains air in the pores and provides internal resistance, compaction of the membrane, and/or lower inherent porosity/pore size of the membrane surface. We also identified solution chemistries and operational conditions that result in different depths of wetting penetration.

 

Our results improve the mechanistic understanding of the MD wetting process and facilitate prediction of wetting during MD. Our results have direct implications for improved wetting resistance through membrane design and process modification, for both conventional and challenging applications. The novel method we developed to characterize membrane deformation has implications for detecting and predicting membrane performance and fatigue for a broad range of water treatment membranes. Finally, our results not only further fundamental understanding of wetting resistance in MD membranes but also have implications for understanding and quantifying membrane wettability in membrane contactors, as well as other processes in which liquid penetration into a porous substrate depends on material properties and environmental conditions.

 

This grant led to the publication of three papers and one doctoral dissertation. Two additional manuscripts and two additional doctoral dissertations are in preparation. This grant also supported the participation of graduate students in technical conferences as well as outreach programs. The outreach programs paired graduate student mentors with high school students for summer research experiences, where mentors guided high school students in developing and completing a research project, presenting results in a formal poster session, and preparing college applications.
